docs.title: Welcome to the Cognition and Memory Lab!
About us
docs.text:
We are a cognitive psychology and neuroscience lab based in the Department of Psychology at Oberlin College!

At the Cognition and Memory Lab, we examine how our internal cognitive states (e.g. our attention, intentions, etc.) during an experience can influence memory organization and retrieval, and how these processes differ in individuals with cogntive differences.

We use a range of methods, including lab-based and online behavioral studies, computational modeling, eye-tracking, and pupillometry to address these questions.

Undergraduate students at Oberlin College play a central role in our research, leading studies and experiments within this research program, resulting in conference presentations and publications.

docs.title: Lab News
docs.text:
Summer 2025: CML welcomes our two summer research assitants - Laura Sanchez & Alina Stoll.

Spring 2025: CML welcomes our first research assistant, Olivia Pickens.

Spring 2025: The Cognition and Memory Lab launches at Oberlin College!

docs.title: Letter of Recommendation
docs.text:
If you are looking for details about requesting a letter of recommendation from Prof. Jayakumar, please read these Guidelines for Letter of Recommendations.

Cannot access the linked document?

** Please sign in with your Oberlin Google (Gmail) account to view the document.**

docs.title: Email
docs.text: For all lab-related questions, please contact us at cognitionandmemorylab@gmail.com.

docs.title: Lab Location
docs.text: Department of Psychology Severance Hall 120 West Lorain Street Oberlin, OH 44074

docs.title: Interested in working with us at CML?
docs.text:
While there is no official requirement to join the lab, I do give preference to students who have completed at least one course with me. I strongly recommend that you complete (or concurrently enroll in) Research Methods I when you begin working in my lab.

At this time, there are no open Research Assistant (RA) positions in the lab. If you'd like to get on our waitlist, please fill the form below and we'll reach out to you when a spot opens up.

Need permission for the form below?

Please sign in with your Oberlin Email (Google Account) to access the form.*

Loading…

docs.title: Collborators
docs.text: Dr. Mariam Aly, University of California Berkeley Dr. Christopher Baldassano, Columbia University Cecilia Nemeth, Columbia University

docs.title: Selected Conference Presentations from Manasi Jayakumar
docs.text:
For a complete list of conference presentations, please see my CV!

Jayakumar, M., Tsegai-Moore, A.S., Nemeth, C., Aly, M.. (2024, June). Pupil Size at Encoding Predicts Temporal Organization of Memory. Talk presented at the Manhattan Area Memory Meeting, New Haven, CT.

Jayakumar, M., Tsegai-Moore, A.S., Nemeth, C., Khine M.T.o, Aly, M. (2023, November). Pupil-based Measures of Attention and the Temporal Organization of Recall. Poster presented at the Psychonomic Society’s 64th Annual Meeting, San Francisco, CA.[PDF].

Jayakumar, M., Balusu, C., Aly, M. (2021, August). Spontaneous attentional fluctuations and the temporal organization of recall. Poster presented at the Context and Episodic Memory Symposium, Philadelphia, PA. [PDF].

Jayakumar, M., Balusu, C., Aly, M. (2021, March). Spontaneous attentional fluctuations and the temporal organization of recall. Poster presented at the Cognitive Neuroscience Society virtual meeting. [PDF]. [Video of presentation].

Jayakumar, M., de Chastelaine, M., Donley, B.E., Kennedy K., Rugg, M.D. (2016, November). Relationship between episodic memory performance, fMRI correlates of encoding and retrieval and estimates of regional brain structure in older adults. Poster presented at the Society for Neuroscience meeting. San Diego, CA. [PDF].

docs.text: Jayakumar, M., Tsegai-Moore, A., Nemeth, C., Aly, M., (2024). Pupil size at encoding predicts the temporal structure of memory. PsyArXiv.

docs.title: Peer-reviewed Publications
docs.text:
Jayakumar, M., Balusu, C., Aly, M. (2023). Attentional fluctuations and the temporal organization of memory. Cognition, 235, 105408. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cognition.2023.105408. [PDF]. [PsyArXiv]. [OSF]. [self-contained Code Ocean computing enviornment].

Trelle, A. N., Carr, V. A., Wilson, E. N., Swarovski, M. S., Hunt, M. P., Toueg, T. N., Tran, T.T., Channappa, D., Corso, N. K., Thieu, M. K., Jayakumar, M., Nadiadwala, A., Guo, W., Tanner, N. J., Bernstein, J. D., Litovsky, C.P., Guerin, S. A., Guerin, S. A., Harrison, M. B., Rutt, B. K., Deutsch, G. K., Chin, F.T., Davidzon, G.A., Hall, J.N., Sha, S. J., Fredericks, C. A., Andreasson, K.I., Kerchner, G. A., Wagner, A. D., Mormino, E. C. (2021). Association of CSF biomarkers with hippocampal-dependent memory in preclinical Alzheimer disease. Neurology, 96(10), e1470-e1481. [PDF].

Hou, M., de Chastelaine, M., Jayakumar, M., Donley, B. E., & Rugg, M. D. (2020). Recollection-related hippocampal fMRI effects predict longitudinal memory change in healthy older adults. Neuropsychologia, 146, 107537. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuropsychologia.2020.107537.[PDF]

Trelle, A. N., Carr, V. A., Guerin, S. A., Thieu, M. K., Jayakumar, M., Guo, W., Nadiadwala, A., Corso, N. K., Hunt, M. P., Litovsky, C. P., Tanner, N. J., Deutsch, G. K., Bernstein, J. D., Harrison, M. B., Khazenzon, A. M., Jiang, J., Sha, S. J., Fredericks, C. A., Rutt, B. K., Mormino, E. C., Kerchner, G. A., Wagner, A. D. (2020). Hippocampal and cortical mechanisms at retrieval explain variability in episodic remembering in older adults. ELife, 9, e55335. [PDF].

Jayakumar, M.*, Tarder-Stoll, H.*, Dimsdale-Zucker, H.R., Günseli, E., & Aly, M. (2019). Dynamic internal states shape memory retrieval. Neuropsychologia, 138, 107328. [PDF]. *denotes equal contribution
